title: Theory of Algorithms and Computational Methods. Functions Approximations, Numerical Differentiation and Integration (Educational Tasks and Methodological Recommendations)
abstract:
This book is for students who would like to acquire practical skills in the methodology of computational experiment - a powerful tool in solving engineering and science problems. The authors assume that the choice of a physical approximation for the given problem as well as the formulation of a mathematical model has already been made. In other words, it is assumed that a mathematical model of the process or phenomenon under consideration has already been constructed. Hence, in this textbook, they focus on the subsequent stages of the computational experiment: (a) design of an efficient numerical method for the solution of the problem (design of a computational algorithm); (b) creating a computer code which implements that method (algorithm); (c) carrying out computations and the analysis of the numerical results obtained. The authors emphasize that after the last stage, it may be necessary to carry out a refinement of the mathematical model that has been used to study the process or phenomenon and to repeat the technological cycle of the computational experiment with the new, refined mathematical model. Each topic presented by the authors is accompanied by computational codes written in FORTRAN. Along with the actual algorithms and computational codes, students will find all the necessary theoretical material covering two topics in numerical methods: functions approximations and numerical differentiation and integration.

This book is addressed mainly to undergraduate 3rd year students in engineering, mathematics, and sciences.

title: Foundations of the Theory of Computational Algorithms. Functions Approximations, Numerical Differentiation and Integration, Linear Algebra
abstract: This textbook presents a comprehensive treatment of theory and applications of computational algorithms, giving special attention to foundational topics. The authors start from fundamental concepts of algorithms, explore deep connections between mathematical logic and theory of algorithm, and provide details on formalization procedures of the notion of algorithm. The latter includes the principle of algorithm normalization, introduction to Markov’s normal algorithms, and their applications. The regularizing algorithms are explained based on ill-posed problems arising from incomplete data. The remaining parts of the book cover in detail topics ranging from discrete and continuous function approximations to numerical methods for differentiation and integration. The authors argue that the majority of problems in computational mathematics, science, and engineering, both linear and nonlinear, are reduced in the end to the solution of systems of linear algebraic equations. Therefore, an extensive chapter in the book is devoted to numerical methods dealing with such systems. Among others, it includes also sections on sparse and non-symmetric systems, as well as on important classes of eigenvalue problems. Theoretical material in the book is illustrated by multiple examples throughout the text, and a set of additional problems is given at the end of the book. The material in the book is centered around the idea that the computer experiment and simulation (CES) represents a key methodology for new discoveries. At the same time, the theory of computational algorithms is receiving an important stimulus for development due to an increasing range of CES applications. This book is intended for students and researchers, as well as for practitioners in the fields of computational mathematics, science, and engineering.

title: Optimization Theory: Elements of Decision Theory, Algorithms of Nonlinear Unconstrained Optimization (Educational Tasks and Methodological Recommendations)
abstract: The book presents decision analysis and optimization in a unified manner. It provides details of the raise of decision making as a scientific discipline, main concepts of the theory of decision making, formulations of the associated optimization problems, and numerical methods for their solution.  The authors explain close connections of the theory of decision making with operations research, and other areas such as cybernetics and Artificial Intelligence (AI). Operations research is understood as a field developing scientific methods for obtaining optimal solutions which are derived based on mathematical models, optimization, statistics, and algorithms.  Details are provided for a number of situations and classes of problems such as multicriteria problems of mathematical programming, as well as decision making and optimization under uncertainty. In the latter context, the authors explain the Bayesian approach, the connection between a priori and a posteriori probabilities, and provide details of formal structures for decision making.  Measures of sensitivity to parameters and entropy-based concepts are also discussed, as well as the key criteria of decision making, including the minimax, Bayes-Laplace, and Savage criteria, along with auxiliary criteria (Hurwicz,  Hodges-Lehman, Germeyer), and different possible choices of the goal functions. The introduction to the risk analysis is also given, with details on confidence intervals and  prognostic factors. In the context of multicriteria decision-making problems, the application of the Pareto optimal principle is explained and elements of  the theory of fuzzy sets are highlighted.  In terms of algorithms for numerical optimization, both cases of one-dimensional and multi-dimensional problems receive quite a comprehensive treatment in the book. The methodologies considered in the book range from the Monte Carlo to heuristic methodologies such as Nelder-Mead.  Each corresponding topic is accompanied by a suggested set of exercises, as well as computational codes, some of which can be used for practical problems of interest, e.g. in queuing theory and operations research. This book is addressed mainly to students in engineering, mathematics, and sciences, but it can be useful for researchers and practitioners interested in these topics.

title: Computational Methods: Linear Algebra problems; Nonlinear Equations and Systems Numerical Solution (Educational Tasks and Methodological Recommendations)
abstract: The book is aimed at students who seek to strengthen their skills in theory and practice of numerical analysis and methods. Many problems that modern engineers and scientists have to solve can be assisted by numerical experiments.  This concerns both, the stage of design, when the numerical experiment is carried out on the design objects, and the stage of the analysis of the physics of fundamentally new elements and constructions. Today, a close collaboration between engineering disciplines and mathematics is not only useful but also routinely necessary.  An alternative to the numerical experiment sometimes can be based on technological experiments. However, such experiments are usually connected with enormous actual costs and time. Therefore, the methodology of the numerical (computational) experiment more and more penetrates into the modelling of technological processes as well.  The current book is devoted to some of the foundational blocks of this methodology and includes such important sections of numerical analysis as computational methods of linear algebra and methods of solving nonlinear equations and systems. The book offers a comprehensive treatment of many algorithms, provides details on their advantages and drawbacks, and presents computational codes for solving a series of problems on the computer. Each topic is supplemented by a set of suggested tasks for practice. The test suits undergraduate students in engineering, mathematics, and sciences.

title: Computational Methods: Ordinary Differential Equations and Equations with Partial Derivatives (Educational Tasks and Methodological Recommendations)
abstract: The necessity of a knowledge of methods for solving differential equations comes from their wide range of applicability. In practical applications, such equations rarely admit analytical solutions. On the other hand, solving such equations is a substantially more complex task compared to the calculation of  one-dimensional integrals based on numerical quadratures. In the first part of this book, the authors  provide an in-depth treatment of numerical methods for solving  ordinary differential equations (ODEs), including both one-step and multi-step methods. This is followed by an extensive discussion of boundary value problems  for ODEs, including systems of equations. The topic of partial differential equations (PDEs) is presented in the book starting with the first-order equations where the authors provide details on quasi-linear equations, discontinuous solutions, and the method of characteristics.  The reader sees how the method of characteristics is generalized to the systems of questions of the first order.  The description of numerical solutions of PDEs of the second order is exemplified by elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic equations.  This topic also includes decomposition methodologies, as well as various iterative schemes and methods of the variational type.  Theoretical material is illustrated by examples. Suggested sets of exercises and computational codes are also provided. The book is mainly addressed to students in engineering, mathematics, and sciences, but researchers and practitioners interested in these topics can also find the material useful for their practical applications.

title: Optimization Theory: Computational Methods in Constrained and Discrete Optimization (Educational Tasks and Methodological Recommendations)
abstract: The book provides theoretical and practical materials for those who would like to obtain more detailed knowledge on the solution of optimization problems under constraints, as well as on solving problems of discrete optimization. As such, it can be used in courses on mathematical programming and operations research. While presenting the material on constrained optimization problems, the authors provide details on the direct methods, as well as the methodologies based on Kuhn-Tucker conditions. Various types of constraints are considered, along with Lagrangean and penalty-type methods. The second part of the book is devoted to methods of linear and dynamic programming. It includes  also the concept of duality, its application, as well as details on integer programming, mixed problems, and state-of-the-art methods of discrete optimization.  While the book has been written for university students, it can also be useful for researchers and practitioners interested in practical tools for solving constrained and discrete optimization problems in their specific applied domains.

title: Foundations of Computational Algorithms Theory: Functions Approximation, Numerical Differentiation and Integration, Linear Algebra
abstract: This textbook presents a comprehensive treatment of theory and applications of computational algorithms, giving special attention to foundational topics. The authors start from fundamental concepts of algorithms, explore deep connections between mathematical logic and theory of algorithm, and provide details on formalization procedures of the notion of algorithm. The latter includes the principle of algorithm normalization, introduction to Markov’s normal algorithms, and their applications. The regularizing algorithms are explained based on ill-posed problems arising from incomplete data. The authors argue that the majority of problems in computational mathematics, science, and engineering, both linear and nonlinear, are reduced in the end to the solution of systems of linear algebraic equations.  Therefore, an extensive chapter in the book is devoted to numerical methods dealing with such systems. Among others, it includes also sections on sparse and non-symmetric systems, as well as  on important classes of eigenvalue problems. extraInfo:
The first edition of this book was published a year ago with a limited number of copied that appeared in print. Upon a request from the publisher, a new edition of this book has been prepared.

2nd Edition, ISBN 5-7763-05-03-9

title: Difference Schemes for Modelling of Nonlocally Connected Processes in Semiconductor Devices
abstract: In the heart of the automated design of components of integrated circuits and microchips lies the possibility of adequate mathematical modelling of multiphysics processes that are behind their functions and characteristics. Such processes are intrinsically interconnected. In this book, a general framework for modelling such processes has been developed. First, a hierarchy of mathematical models is discussed based on  comparing the role of particle collisions with other scattering mechanisms. It is argued that the modelling of transport phenomena in semiconductors can be efficiently carried out via relaxation-time approximations. While the Liouville-type models for the evolution of the position-velocity probability density face serious challenges in their numerical implementations, the introduction of  momentum and energy relaxation times allows us to construct a hierarchy of the models, including kinetic, hydrodynamic, and drift-diffusion types. The latter type of models can be justified rigorously via a Hilbert expansion only for low carrier densities and small electric fields. With further miniaturization and scaling of integrated circuits and their components, this group of models is becoming increasingly inadequate to describe complex non-equilibrium and nonlocal processes in semiconductor plasma. Nevertheless, the solutions to such models can still be useful as initial approximations for the models standing higher in the modelling hierarchy. In this book, the author focuses on quasi-hydrodynamic models which provides a reasonable compromise between kinetic and hydrodynamic types of models. Such models consist of coupled systems of partial differential equations that include the Maxwell-Poisson, continuity, and energy balance equations for particle components of electron-hole plasma. Details of the development of efficient computational approximations to such models are given together with their algorithmic realizations, stability conditions, convergence analysis, and examples. The models considered in this book belong to a wider class of nonlocal models. They can be useful in modelling of superconductor superlattices in acousto- and optoelectronics, as well as in the design of such devices as semiconductor lasers, liquid crystal displays, light-emitting diodes, and thin-film devices, to name just a few. The book is aimed at researchers working in mathematical modelling of complex dynamic systems, phenomena, and processes.

title: Introduction to Computational Algorithms: Nonlinear Equations and Systems, Numerical Integration of Differential Equations
abstract: This book covers a selection of topics in numerical analysis and aims at undergraduate students in engineering, mathematics, and sciences. The main focus is made on handling nonlinear problems. The first part of the book is devoted to solutions of nonlinear equations in one variable, and to numerical solutions of nonlinear systems of equations. The second part of the book provides details on modern numerical methodologies for solving differential equations. Special attention is given to stiff systems and applied practical methods for their solution.

title: Topics in Calculus for Decision Theory, Optimisation, and Computational Methods (Educational Tasks and Methodological Recommendations)
abstract: Modern applications of mathematical programming, operations research, and theory of decision making are based on mathematical foundations at the level of calculus and mathematical analysis. However, many texts, and in particular those oriented to engineering or business and economics students, in courses such as decision theory and optimization are lacking such foundations. This book aims at filling this gap in the existing literature. The authors provide all necessary mathematical background and preliminaries in calculus for successful studies of decision theory and optimization, with special attention given to computational approaches. While the book has been written with undergraduate students in mind, some topics could provide useful information for graduate students and researchers interested in numerical methods applied in the areas mentioned.

title: Computer-Aided Design of VLSI (for graduate students)
abstract: The book is oriented towards the electronic engineering students, as well as towards the students in other engineering disciplines, applied, and industrial mathematics who are interested in computer-aided design (CAD) technologies and their applications. The book focuses on the process of creating integrated circuits by combining a huge number of electronic components onto a single chip. This process, known as Very Large-Scale Integration or VLSI,  has become dominant in semiconductor, telecommunication, and other technologies. Today, the creation, modification, analysis, and optimization of VLSI designs are impossible without the computer. The book describes in detail the modern methods of CAD in the context of VLSI. Many examples are given in the context of microprocessors which provide a classical example of VLSI devices. Implications of CAD programs for other disciplines and their influence on research in computational geometry and computer graphics  are also discussed, with highlights of the most recent trends in the development of CAD techniques given.

title: Advanced Engineering Mathematics (64636)
abstract: This book  is oriented towards engineering students and aims to assist the students to gain proficiency in applying mathematics to engineering problems. It covers the following five modules: (a)  the numerical solution of partial differential equations; (b) stochastic process modelling; (c)  time series analysis and forecasting; (d) linear operators and functional analysis; (e) advanced numerical methods. The latter module includes multigrid and finite element methods. Theoretical material is illustrated by practical examples throughout the book.

title: DDNS Book Review: Idempotency
abstract: Idempotency refers to the study of semirings in which the addition operation is idempotent. The theory of these abstract algebraic structures has been under development at least since the 1950s largely due to early observations that certain problems of discrete optimization could be linearized over suitable idempotent semirings. Now it is also clear that there are intrinsic connections of idempotency with computer science and other disciplines. This a review of the book written by one of the experts in this field.
journal: International Journal of Discrete Dynamics in Nature and Society
extraInfo: DDNS Book Review by Melnik, R.V.N.: Idempotency, J. Gunawardena (ed). Cambridge University, the Newton Institute, 1998, 443pp., ISBN 0-521-55344-X

title: New Methods in Applied and Computational Mathematics (NEMACOM98)
abstract: It is an edited volume of selected papers from the NEMACOM-98 (New Methods in Applied and Computational Mathematics), a workshop that took place in July 1998 in Queensland, Australia, and was supported by the Australian Mathematical Society and the Numerical Algorithms Group in Oxford, UK. The topics presented were ranging from computational statistics and stochastic processes, through optimization, optimal control, graph theoretic methods in computational mathematics, the use of dynamical systems techniques for meteorology, modelling of the solar atmosphere and geo-hydrological processes, simulating rigid-body dynamics, and the future of the Fast Fourier Transform.
journal: Proceedings of the Centre for Mathematics and its Applications, ANU
extraInfo: ISBN 0 7315 5202 4

title: Mathematics for Industry in Denmark
abstract: The editorial, published by the ECME, is about the 47th European Study Group with Industry, held in Sønderborg, Denmark, August 24 - 29, 2003. Such Study Groups represent a forum where academic mathematicians work on problems directly related to the industry. The history of such workshops goes back to 1963 when  the Oxford Study Group with Industry was initiated by Alan Tayler. Later, the European Consortium for Mathematics in Industry (ECMI) was organized and the name of the European Study Group with Industry (ESGI), as an internationally recognized method of technology transfer between academic mathematicians and industry, has started being used. At the ECMI Council meeting in 1997, the decision was made that Study Groups should also be held outside Great Britain, and the 47th European Study Group with Industry in Denmark was one such example.  For the first time, the conference took place in the Sønderborg area. A large number of high-technological companies create growth and dynamics in the area and make the region one of the most important centers for information technology, telecommunication, and electronics in Denmark. Sønderborg is a port, an industrial and commercial center, and a seaside resort. It is a city where the historic past meets the future. During the meeting, five working groups were formed who successfully tackled presented industrial challenges. In particular, industrial projects included  Project 1: Stall Prediction Model (Grundfos), Project 2: Model to Check Distance to Catalog Curve (Grundfos), Project 3: Mathematical Analysis of the Dynamic Flow Characteristic in a Damping Nozzle for a Pressure Transmitter (Danfoss Industrial Controls), Project 4: Trigger Algorithm for Ultrasonic Flow Metering (Danfoss Flow Division), and Project 5: Determination of Distance from a 2D Picture (Unisensor). In conjunction with the meeting a number of talks were presented. Among them, on “Industry & Science Collaborations” by Frands Voss (MCI Director, USD), on “Computational Methods for Estimation in the Presence of Uncertainty” by  H. Thomas Banks (Director of Center for Research in Scientific Computation, North Carolina State University), on “Computational Modelling of Industrial Operations Involving Multi-physics and Multi-scale Processes” by  Mark Cross (Director of the Centre for Numerical Modelling and Process Analysis,  University of Greenwich), and on “Mathematical Models of Hysteresis” by Martin Brokate (Chair of Numerical Mathematics and Control, Technical University of Munich).
extraInfo: This editorial was published by the European Consortium for Mathematics in Industry, Number 34, October, 2003.

title: Wave Phenomena in Physics and Engineering: New Models, Algorithms, and Applications.
journal: Special Issue of Mathematics and Computers in Simulation
extraInfo:
This is a special issue on “Wave Phenomena in Physics and Engineering: New Models, Algorithms, and Applications”. A detailed description is given in the guest editorial. Here we list the contributions that appeared in this special issue:

  1. Preconditioning techniques for the solution of the Helmholtz equation by the finite element method (by Riyad Kechroud, Azzeddine Soulaimani, Yousef Saad, Shivaraju Gowda);
  2. Optimization of power in the problems of active control of sound (by J. Lončarić, S.V. Tsynkov);
  3. Helmholtz equation in parabolic rotational coordinates: application to wave problems in quantum mechanics and acoustics (by L.C. Lew Yan Voon, M. Willatzen);
  4. Monte Carlo modeling of spin FETs controlled by spin–orbit interaction (by Min Shen, Semion Saikin, Ming-C. Cheng, Vladimir Privman);
  5. Furnace geometry effects on plume dynamics in laser ablation for nanotube synthesis (by Diomar Cesar Lobão, Alex Povitsky);
  6. Quantum confinement phenomena in nanowire superlattice structures (by M. Willatzen, R.V.N. Melnik, C. Galeriu, L.C. Lew Yan Voon);
  7. Numerical simulations of laminar mixing surfaces in pulsatile microchannel flows (by Darren L. Hitt, Matthew McGarry);
  8. Spherical Richtmyer-Meshkov instability for axisymmetric flow (by Srabasti Dutta, James Glimm, John W. Grove, David H. Sharp, Yongmin Zhang);
  9. Richtmyer–Meshkov instability in liquid metal flows: influence of cavitation and magnetic fields (by Roman Samulyak, Yarema Prykarpatskyy);
  10. Effect of vortex profile on sound generation in a non-uniform flow (by Alex Povitsky, Tinghui Zheng, Georgios H. Vatistas);
  11. Instability-wave propagation in boundary-layer flows at subsonic through hypersonic Mach numbers (by Li Jiang, Chau-Lyan Chang, Meelan Choudhari, Chaoqun Liu);
  12. Applications of fully conservative schemes in nonlinear thermoelasticity: modelling shape memory materials (by P. Matus, R.V.N. Melnik, L. Wang, I. Rybak);
  13. On self-drifting flame balls (by Kagan, S. Minaev, G. Sivashinsky);
  14. Quantification of the CARI breast imaging sensitivity by 2D/3D numerical time-domain ultrasound wave propagation (by A. Bounaïm, S. Holm, W. Chen, Å. Ødegård);
  15. Exact solutions and invariants of motion for general types of regularized long wave equations (by S. Hamdi, W.H. Enright, W.E Schiesser, J.J. Gottlieb). 


ISSN 0378-4754, 248 Pages

title: Modelling, control and analysis of coupled problems, processes and phenomena. The Fourth World Congress of Nonlinear Analysts
extraInfo:
This is a special issues on “Modelling, control and analysis of coupled problems, processes and phenomena” based on selected papers presented at the Forth World Congress of Nonlinear Analysts. Among those presented as one-hour invited talks were the following: (a) Optimization-Based Methods for Effecting Multidisciplinary Simulation and Optimization (by Max Gunzburger , Florida State University); (b) Applications of Nonlinear Analysis to Cell Biology (by Jack Tuszynski, University of Alberta, co-authored with S. Portet, University of Toronto and J. Dixon, University of Warwick); (c) Control Bifurcations (by Arthur J. Krener , University of California Davis). A detailed description is given in the guest editorial. Here we list the contributions that appeared in this special issue:

  1. Exact solutions and conservation laws for coupled generalized Korteweg–de Vries and quintic regularized long wave equations (by Hamdi, W.H. Enright, W. E Schiesser, J.J. Gottlieb);
  2. Analysis of coupling between hydrodynamic and thermal instabilities in non-Boussinesq convection (by Sergey A. Suslov);
  3. A non-conforming computational methodology for modeling coupled problems (by E. Aulisa, S. Manservisi, P. Seshaiyer);
  4. Concerning the exact null controllability of a nonlinear thermoelastic plate (by George Avalos);
  5. Description of adhering with saturation using boundary conditions of hysteresis type (by N. D. Botkin, K.-H. Hoffmann, A.M. Meirmanov, V.N. Starovoitov);
  6. A posteriori error estimate techniques for coupled Navier–Stokes equations and energy equation (by J. Cao);
  7. Competitive permeation of calcium ions through the calcium release channel (by Ryanodine receptor) of cardiac muscle: An application of the coupled Poisson–Nernst–Planck system of equations (by Duan P. Chen);
  8. The role of spatio-temporal effects in anaerobic digestion of solid waste (by Hermann J. Eberl);
  9. Dynamics of SHS in periodic media (by Michael Frankel and Victor Roytburd);
  10. Viscous forces on acoustically levitated gas bubbles (by Darren L. Hitt and Andrea Prosperetti);
  11. An overview of modelling challenges for a nonlinear plate-beam model (by Mary Ann Horn and Günter Leugering);
  12. Numerical modeling for design of viscoelastic coatings with favorable sound absorbing properties (by S. Ivansson);
  13. A local surface model applied to contact line dynamics (by J. Monnier and P. Witomski);
  14. The Lax–Friedrichs sweeping method for optimal control problems in continuous and hybrid dynamics (by Chiu Yen Kao, Carmeliza Navasca, Stanley Osher);
  15. Three-dimensional flow in cavity at yaw (by Alex Povitsky);
  16. Solution techniques for multi-physics problems with application to computational nonlinear aeroelasticity (by Azzeddine Soulaımani, Zhengkun Feng, Amin Ben Haj Ali);
  17. A higher-order time integration algorithm for the simulation of nonlinear fluid–structure interaction (by A.H. van Zuijlen and H. Bijl);
  18. Non-linear strain theory for low-dimensional semiconductor structures (by B. Lassen, R. Melnik, M. Willatzen, L.C. Lew Yan Voon);
  19. Electrostatic coupling of MEMS structures: transient simulations and dynamic pull-in (by V. Rochus, D.J. Rixen, J.-C. Golinval);
  20. Radiation-coupled front-tracking simulations for laser-driven shock experiments (by Yongmin Zhang, R. Paul Drake, James Glimm, John W. Grove, David H. Sharp).

title: Methods of Mathematical and Computational Physics for Industry, Science, and Technology
journal: Special Issue of the Journal of Physics: Conf. Ser.
extraInfo:
This is a special issue on “Methods of Mathematical and Computational Physics for Industry, Science, and Technology”. A detailed description is given in the guest editorial. Here we list the contributions that appeared in this special issue:

  1. Flow-Acoustic Properties of Elliptic-Cylinder Waveguides and Enclosures (by Morten Willatzen and Lok C Lew Yan Voon);
  2. Detection of time of arrival of ultrasonic pulses (by Carl D Latino, Niels Lervad Andersen and Frands Voss);
  3. Distance of Sample Measurement Points to Prototype Catalog Curve (by Poul G Hjorth, Mirza Karamehmedović, John Perram, Robert Piché, Ulrik Ullum and Michael Krätzschmar);
  4. Prediction of rotating stall within an impeller of a centrifugal pump based on spectral analysis of pressure and velocity data (by Ulrik Ullum, Jennifer Wright, Oguz Dayi, Ali Ecder, Azzeddine Soulaimani, Robert Piché and Hemant Kamath);
  5. Determination of Distance from a 2D Picture (by J Gravesen, B Lassen, R Melnik, B Picasso, R Piché, N Radulovic and L X Wang);
  6. Arrival-Time Detection and Ultrasonic Flow-Meter Applications (by Morten Willatzen, Peter Søndergaard, Carl Latino, Frands Voss, Niels Lervad Andersen, Martin Brokate and Aicha Bounaim);
  7. Exhaustive global grid search in computing receiver position from modular satellite range measurements (by Niilo Sirola);
  8. Mathematical analysis of the dynamic flow characteristic in a damping nozzle for a pressure transmitter (by P D Howel, A A Lacey, J Vogler and A Vonsild).

title: Modelling coupled and transport phenomena in nanotechnology
journal: Special Issue of the Journal of Computational and Theoretical Nanoscience
extraInfo:
This is a special issue on “Modelling coupled and transport phenomena in nanotechnology”. A detailed description is given in the guest editorial. Here we list the contributions that appeared in this special issue:

  1. Advanced Approach to Modelling Quantum Well Semiconductor Lasers Based on the Quantum Boltzmann Equation: Green's Function Approach, pp. 463-478(16), by Weetman, Philip; Wartak, Marek S.
  2. Stochastic Clustering and Self-Organization of Gross Deformation and Phason Activity in Quasicrystals: Modeling and Simulations, pp. 479-486(8), by Mariano, Paolo Maria; Stazi, Furio Lorenzo; Gioffrè, Massimiliano
  3. Computational Study Investigating the Influence of Long-Range Repulsive Forces on the Collective Behaviour of Particulate Media, pp. 487-496(10), by Antony, S. J.; Sarangi, F.
  4. Transport, Growth, and Stability of Disturbances in Weakly Rarefied Channel Flows, pp. 497-505(9), by Fedele, Francesco; Hitt, Darren L.
  5. Modeling Liquid Transport in Fibrous Structures: An Multi-Scale Approach, pp. 506-512(7), by Zhong, Wen; Pan, Ning; Lukas, David
  6. Comparison of 1-D and 2-D Coupled Models of Gas Dynamics and Heat Transfer for the Laser Ablation of Carbon, pp. 513-524(12), by Mullenix, Nathan; Povitsky, Alex
  7. Multi-Level Boundary Element Method: Novel Computational Tool for Large-Scale Heat Conduction Simulations, pp. 525-537(13), by Grigoriev, M. M.; Dargush, G. F.
  8. A Computational–Experimental Thermomechanical Study of Shape Memory Alloy Microcoils and Its Application to the Design of Actuators, pp. 538-550(13), by Velázquez, Ramiro; Hafez, Moustapha; Pissaloux, Edwige; Szewczyk, Jérôme
  9. Influence of the Metal Contact Size on the Electron Dynamics and Transport Inside the Semiconductor Heterostructure Nanowire, pp. 551-559(9), by Radulovic, Nenad; Willatzen, Morten; Melnik, Roderick V. N.; Lew Yan Voon, Lok C.
  10. Higher Order Regularization of Anisotropic Geometric Evolution Equations in Three Dimensions, pp. 560-564(5), by Rätz, Andreas; Voigt, Axel
  11. Inviscid, Viscous, and Turbulent Models of Plume Dynamics for Laser Ablation of Carbon, pp. 565-578(14), by Pathak, Kedar; Povitsky, Alex
  12. Inclusion of Nonlinear Strain Effects in the Hamiltonian for Nanoscale Semiconductor Structures, pp. 588-597(10), by Lassen, B.; Willatzen, M.; Melnik, R.
  13. A Thermal Model Based on the Lattice Boltzmann Method for Low Mach Number Compressible Flows, pp. 579-587(9), by Tölke, Jonas

title: Methods of Computational Mechanics for Industry, Science, and Technology
journal: Special Issue of the International Journal for Computational Methods in Engineering Science and Mechanics
extraInfo: This is a special issue on “Methods of Computational Mechanics for Industry, Science, and Technology”. It covers state-of-the-art advancements in a range of areas in computational solid and fluid mechanics, as well as in modern computational techniques, including high performance computing. Among them (a) Multiscale Considerations in Modeling of Nonlinear Elastomers (by H. T. Banks, Negash G. Medhin, and Gabriella A. Pinter), (b) Computational Modelling of Multi-Physics and Multi-Scale Processes in Parallel (by M. Cross, T. N. Croft, A. K. Slone, A. J. Williams, N. Christakis, M. K. Patel, C. Bailey, and K. Pericleous), (c) Numerical Tracking of Shallow Water Waves by the Unstructured Finite Volume WAF Approximation (by Youssef Loukili and Azzeddine Soulaïmani), (d) An Algorithm for Solving Reactive Advection-Dispersion Problems (by J. Cao and P. K. Kitanidis), (e) Multiple-Domain Analysis of Combustion of a Spherical Fuel Droplet (Ali Ecder and Raif Unsal).

title: Mathematical Models and Computational Methods for Nano- and Bio-Technologies
abstract: Hand in hand with the development of new nano- and bio-technologies has come an increasing need for new mathematical models that describe systems, phenomena, and processes associated with these technologies. In many cases, such mathematical models are being developed as coupled systems of differential/difference and/or integral equations that require efficient computational techniques for their solution. Scientists and technologists working in industry are often unaware of state-of-the-art developments in mathematical modeling that can be directly pertinent to their problems. At the same time, mathematicians are often unable to tackle challenging new applied problems because they lack knowledge of the domain in which the problems arise. This minisymposium demonstrated some of the key mathematical and computational challenges associated with state-of-the-art developments in nano- and bio-technologies, with the emphasis on important representative examples. At the same time, it exposed the more technologically oriented part of the community to the most advanced mathematical and computational techniques currently being developed, encouraging interdisciplinary collaborations. Indeed, the development and integration of mathematical modeling techniques into nano- and bio-technologies is an essential prerequisite for further progress in this increasingly interdisciplinary field.
extraInfo: The editorial, published by the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM), is about the symposium on “Mathematical Models and Computational Methods for Nano- and Bio-technologies”. The event consisted of two parts and took place at the ICIAM Congress in Zurich (ETH Zurich and Zurich University), July 16 - 20, 2007.

title: Physics-Based Mathematical Models of Low-Dimensional Semiconductor Nanostructures: Analysis and Computation
abstract: Nanotechnology is the study and application of phenomena at or below the dimensions of 100 nm and has received a lot of public attention following popular accounts such as in the bestselling book by Michael Crichton, Prey. It is an area where fundamental questions of applied mathematics and mathematical physics, design of computational methodologies, physical insight, engineering and experimental techniques are meeting together in a quest for an adequate description of nanomaterials and nanostructures for applications in optoelectronics, medicine, energy-saving, bio- and other key technologies which will profoundly influence our life in the 21st century and beyond. There are already hundreds of applications in daily life such as in cosmetics and the hard drives in MP3 players (the 2007 Nobel prize in physics was recently awarded for the science that allowed the miniaturization of the drives), delivering drugs, high-definition DVD players and stain-resistant clothing, but with thousands more anticipated. The focus of this interdisciplinary workshop was on determining what kind of new theoretical and computational tools will be needed to advance the science and engineering of nanomaterials and nanostructures.
journal: Special Issue of the Journal of Physics: CS
extraInfo:
This is a special issue on “Physics-Based Mathematical Models of Low-Dimensional Semiconductor Nanostructures: Analysis and Computation”. A detailed description is given in the guest editorial. Here we list the contributions that appeared in this special issue:

  1. Electromechanical fields in GaN/AlN wurtzite quantum dots, by D Barettin, B Lassen and M Willatzen
  2. Theoretical model for the detection of charged proteins with a silicon-on-insulator sensor, by S Birner, C Uhl, M Bayer and P Vogl
  3. Growth, optical properties and device characterisation of InAs/GaAs quantum dot bilayers, by E Clarke, P Spencer, E Harbord, P Howe and R Murray
  4. Modeling and simulation of field-effect biosensors (BioFETs) and their deployment on the nanoHUB, by C Heitzinger, R Kennell, G Klimeck, N Mauser, M McLennan and C Ringhofer
  5. Influence of many-particle interactions on slow light phenomena in quantum dots, by J Houmark, A-P Jauho, T R Nielsen and J Mørk
  6. Predictive modelling of nanorods synthesis, by H Huang
  7. 3D NEGF quantum transport simulator for modeling ballistic transport in nano FinFETs, by H R Khan, D Mamaluy and D Vasileska
  8. Electromechanical effects in electron structure for GaN/AlN quantum dots, by B Lassen, M Willatzen, D Barettin, R V N Melnik and L C Lew Yan Voon
  9. From k.p to atomic calculations applied to semiconductor heterostructures, by L Pedesseau, C Cornet, F Doré, J Even, A Schliwa and D Bimberg
  10. Dipole nano-laser, by I E Protsenko, A V Uskov, K E Krotova and E P O'Reilly
  11. Physics-based mathematical models for quantum devices via experimental system identification, by S G Schirmer, D K L Oi and S J Devitt
  12. Non-Markovian dynamics of charge carriers in quantum dots, by E Vaz and J Kyriakidis

title: Mathematical and Computational Models for Transport and Coupled Processes in Micro- and Nanotechnology
abstract: As the range of applications of micro- and nanostructures continues to grow, the role of mathematical models and computational experiments in this field becomes increasingly important. Designing of and working with structures and devices on scales between a nanometer and a micron bring new fundamental challenges that can be addressed by combined efforts of researchers working in chemical kinetics, micro-scale fluid dynamics, heat-transfer, mathematical modeling, micro-scale solid mechanics and solid-state physics. We hope that this special issue will be a useful reference for the researchers studying coupled and transport processes at micro- and nano- scale and will help strengthen interdisciplinary collaboration in this important field of nanoscience and nanotechnology.
journal: Special Issue of Journal of the Nanoscience and Nanotechnology
extraInfo:
This is a special issue on “Mathematical and Computational Models for Transport and Coupled Processes in Micro- and Nanotechnology”. A detailed description is given in the guest editorial. Here we list the contributions that appeared in this special issue:

  1. Design of Spintronic Materials with Simple Structures, pp. 3652-3660(9), Authors: Fong, C. Y.; Qian, M. C.; Liu, Kai; Yang, L. H.; Pask, J. E.
  2. Non-Equilibrium Molecular Dynamics Simulation of Nanojet Injection with Adaptive-Spatial Decomposition Parallel Algorithm, pp. 3661-3673(13), Authors: Shin, Hyun-Ho; Yoon, Woong-Sup
  3. A Numerical Algorithm for Magnetohydrodynamics of Ablated Materials, pp. 3674-3685(12), Authors: Lu, Tianshi; Du, Jian; Samulyak, Roman
  4. Computational Models in Nano-Bioelectronics: Simulation of Ionic Transport in Voltage Operated Channels, pp. 3686-3694(9), Authors: Longaretti, Massimo; Marino, Giovambattista; Chini, Bice; Jerome, Joseph W.; Sacco, Riccardo
  5. Efficient Numerical Schemes for Electronic States in Coupled Quantum Dots, pp. 3695-3709(15), Authors: Hwang, Tsung-Min; Wang, Wei-Hua; Wang, Weichung
  6. Enhanced Thermal Conductivity of Nanofluids Diagnosis by Molecular Dynamics Simulations, pp. 3710-3718(9), Authors: Teng, Kuo-Liang; Hsiao, Pai-Yi; Hung, Shih-Wei; Chieng, Ching-Chang; Liu, Ming-Shen; Lu, Ming-Chang
  7. Effects of Ampholyte Dissociation Constants on Protein Separation in On-Chip Isoelectric Focusing, pp. 3719-3728(10), Authors: Shim, Jaesool; Dutta, Prashanta; Ivory, Cornelius F.
  8. Quasicontinuum-Like Reduction of Density Functional Theory Calculations of Nanostructures, pp. 3729-3740(12), Authors: Negrut, Dan; Anitescu, Mihai; El-Azab, Anter; Zapol, Peter
  9. Effect of Slip Boundary Condition on the Design of Nanoparticle Focusing Lenses, pp. 3741-3748(8), Authors: Cho, Dae-Geun; Na, Jung-Gil; Choi, Jae-Boong; Kim, Young-Jin; Kim, Taesung
  10. A Penalty Method to Model Particle Interactions in DNA-Laden Flows, pp. 3749-3756(8), Authors: Trebotich, D.; Miller, G. H.; Bybee, M. D.
  11. An Atomistically Enriched Continuum Model for Nanoscale Contact Mechanics and Its Application to Contact Scaling, pp. 3757-3773(17), Authors: Sauer, Roger A.; Li, Shaofan
  12. Stiffness and Thickness of Boron-Nitride Nanotubes, pp. 3774-3780(7), Authors: Song, J.; Wu, J.; Huang, Y.; Hwang, K. C.; Jiang, H.
  13. Method of Submerged Stokeslets for Slip Flow About Ensembles of Particles, pp. 3790-3801(12), Authors: Zhao, Shunliu; Povitsky, Alex
  14. Kinetic Theory Analysis of Laser Ablation of Carbon, pp. 3781-3789(9), Author: Shusser, Michael

title: Nanoscale Processes, Modeling Coupled and Transport Phenomena in Nanotechnology
abstract: This is an encyclopedic entry that appeared in the Encyclopedia of Complexity and Systems Science under the title “Nanoscale Processes, Modeling Coupled and Transport Phenomena in Nanotechnology”. It focuses of multiple scales and coupled effects in modelling low dimensional semiconductor nanostructures as a representative example of complex systems considered between atomistic and continuum worlds.
journal: Encyclopedia of Complexity and Systems Science
extraInfo: Editor-in-Chief Meyers, R.A., Springer, ISBN: 978-0-387-75888-6

title: Coupled effects in low-dimensional nanostructures and multiphysics modeling
abstract: In semiconductor superlattices, the bandwidth can be tuned by changing the width of the barriers wells. Such superlattices attracted attention in early 1960s and the early studies of the effect of a periodic modulation of the potential in one direction on the crystal band structure is owing to Keldysh. Later, Esaki, Tsu, and others used 1D models to study transport effects in semiconductor superlattices. In earlier 1970s, heterostructures were realized in the laboratories. Since that time, the ﬁeld of low-dimensional systems and nanostructures has grown substantially and includes now semiconductor heterostructures, quantum wells, superlattices, mesoscopic and 2D electron systems, quantum wires, and quantum dots. The ﬁeld has experienced an unprecedented growth in terms of applications, and in addition to its early focus on semiconductor lasers, it includes now a wealth of applications in optoelectronics, quantum information processing, security and defence, health care and biotechnologies, and among many other areas.
extraInfo:
CONTENTS

  1. Introduction
  2. Low-dimensional nanostructures in a historical context
  3. 1.2. Low-dimensional nanostructures as multiscale complex systems
  4. Hierarchy of Mathematical Models for LDSNs
  5. Studying Properties of LDSNs with Numerical Methodologies
  6. Incorporating New Effects
  7. Coupled electromechanical, nonlocal, and boundary effects
  8. Coupled effects owing to spatiotemporal interactions in LDSNs: transport and control
  9. Coupled thermoelectric and thermomechanical effects
  10. Thermopiezoelectric effects in nanostructures
  11. Magnetic and spin-orbit couplings
  12. Coupling owing to the magnetic field
  13. Spin coupling
  14. Many-body coupled effects
  15. Higher order nonlinear effects
  16. Phase transformations and phase stability in nanostructures
  17. 5. Applications of Low-Dimensional Nanostructures and Concluding Remarks


Editor Nawla, H.S American Scientific Publishers ISBN 1-58883-161-2

title: Advances in Mathematical and Computational Methods: Addressing Modern Challenges of Science, Technology, and Society
abstract: The book provides a unique collection of in-depth technical discussions and exchange of ideas in mathematical and computational sciences, as well as their applications in natural and social sciences, engineering and technology, industry and finance. It aims at researchers, industrialists, engineers and students who want to foster interdisciplinary collaborations required to meet the challenges of modern science, technology, and society. Applied and computational mathematics plays a fundamental role in new discoveries in sciences and engineering. The methodology of mathematical modeling and computational experiment provides a primary and ubiquitous tool in such discoveries, as well as in the development of new theories and techniques for the solution of important problems arising from the sciences and engineering. The main goal of this book is to provide the reader with state-of-the-art achievements in the development of this methodology along with the associated theories and techniques in diverse areas of human knowledge, promoting interdisciplinary interactions between mathematicians, scientists and engineers. The book is a valuable source of the methods, ideas, and tools of applied and computational mathematics developed for other disciplines, including natural and social sciences, engineering and technology. Original results are presented on both fundamental and applied developments, with a wide range of examples emphasizing interdisciplinary nature and universality applied mathematics and mathematical modeling.This book has a number of unique features:  -The book can serve as a reference to state-of-the-art original works on the applications of mathematical and computational methods and tools in disciplines from natural and social sciences to technology and engineering.

title: Mathematics and Life Sciences
abstract:
The book provides a unique collection of in-depth mathematical, statistical, and modeling methods and techniques for life sciences, as well as their applications in a number of areas within life sciences. The book provides also with a range of new ideas that represent emerging frontiers in life sciences where the application of such quantitative methods and techniques is becoming increasingly important.

Many areas within life sciences are becoming increasingly quantitative and the progress in those areas will be more and more dependent on the successful development of advanced mathematical, statistical and modelling methodologies and techniques. The state-of-the-art developments in such methodologies and techniques are scattered throughout research journals and hardly accessible to the practitioners in those areas. This book identifies a number of frontier areas where such methodologies and techniques have recently been developed and are to be published here for the first time, bringing substantial potential benefit to a range of applications in life sciences. In addition, the book contains several state-of-the-art surveys at the interface of mathematics and life sciences that would benefit a larger interdisciplinary community.

It is aimed at researchers in academia, practitioners and graduate students who want to foster interdisciplinary collaborations required to meet the challenges at the interface of modern life sciences and mathematics.
journal: De Gruyter Book Series in Mathematics and Life Sciences
extraInfo: Electronic, First Published: December 19, 2012, ISBN: 9783110288537 and Hardcover, First Published: December 13, 2012, ISBN: 9783110273724

title: Computational Methods for Hyperbolic Problems
abstract: This is an introduction to some of the basic concepts on modern numerical methods for computing approximate solutions to hyperbolic partial differential equations. This chapter is divided into five sections. Section 1 contains a review of some elementary theoretical concepts on hyperbolic equations, mainly focused on the linear case; the Riemann problem for a general linear system with constant coefficients is solved in detail. Section 2 is an introduction to the basics of discretization methods, including finite difference methods and finite volume methods; concepts such as local truncation error, linear stability and modified equation are included; Godunov’s theorem is stated, proved and its implications are discussed. Section 3 contains two approximate Riemann solvers, as applied to the three-dimensional Euler equations, namely HLLC and EVILIN. Section 4 deals with the construction of non-linear (non-oscillatory) numerical methods of the TVD and ENO type, for a scalar conservation law. In Sect. 5 we use the theory developed for scalar equations as a guideline to construct non-linear (quasi non-oscillatory) second-order finite volume schemes for one-dimensional non-linear systems with source terms. Key references for further reading are indicated at the end of each section.
journal: Special Issue of the Journal of Computational Science
extraInfo:
This is a special issue on “Computational Methods for Hyperbolic Problems”. A detailed description is given in the guest editorial. Here we list the contributions that appeared in this special issue:

  1. Pseudospectral methods for Boussinesq-type equations in an annular domain with applications to mid-sized lakes, by D.T. Steinmoeller, M. Stastna, K.G. Lamb
  2. v Central schemes for the modified Buckley–Leverett equation, by Ying Wang, Chiu-Yen Kao
  3. A discontinuous Galerkin method for solutions of the Euler equations on Cartesian grids with embedded geometries, by Ruibin Qin, Lilia Krivodonova
  4. Numerical solutions to shock reflection and shock interaction problems for the self-similar transonic two-dimensional nonlinear wave systems, by Eun Heui Kim, Chung-Min Lee
  5. Efficient determination of the critical parameters and the statistical quantities for Klein–Gordon and sine-Gordon equations with a singular potential using generalized polynomial chaos methods, by Debananda Chakraborty, Jae-Hun Jung
  6. Data and range-bounded polynomials in ENO methods, by Martin Berzins
  7. Two phase simulations of glacier lake outburst flows, by E. Bruce Pitman, Abani K. Patra, Dinesh Kumar, Kouichi Nishimura, Jiro Komori
  8. Locally divergence-free central discontinuous Galerkin methods for ideal MHD equations, by Sergey Yakovlev, Liwei Xu, Fengyan Li
  9. Self-similar solutions for the diffraction of weak shocks, by Allen M. Tesdall, John K. Hunter
  10. A rapid interpolation method of finding vascular CFD solutions with spectral collocation methods, by Jae-Hun Jung, Joseph Lee, Kenneth R. Hoffmann, Todd Dorazio, E. Bruce Pitman
  11. On the numerical approximation of one-dimensional nonconservative hyperbolic systems, by N. Chalmers, E. Lorin

title: Advances in Applied Mathematics, Mathematical Modeling and Computational Science
abstract:
The volume presents a selection of in-depth studies and state-of-the-art surveys of several challenging topics that are at the forefront of modern applied mathematics, mathematical modeling, and computational science. These three areas represent the foundation upon which the methodology of mathematical modeling and computational experiment is built as a ubiquitous tool in all areas of mathematical applications. This book covers both fundamental and applied research, ranging from studies of elliptic curves over finite fields with their applications to cryptography, to dynamic blocking problems, to random matrix theory with its innovative applications. The book provides the reader with state-of-the-art achievements in the development and application of new theories at the interface of applied mathematics, modeling, and computational science.

This book aims at fostering interdisciplinary collaborations required to meet the modern challenges of applied mathematics, modeling, and computational science. At the same time, the contributions combine rigorous mathematical and computational procedures and examples from applications ranging from engineering to life sciences, providing a rich ground for graduate student projects.

title: Soliton-like thermoelastic waves
abstract: This is an encyclopedic entry on “Soliton-Like Thermoelastic Waves”. Solitary waves, or briefly solitons, are remarkable phenomena occurring in many physical, biological, and mechanical systems. Thermoelasticity represents a group of such systems, in which the solitons can be formed under certain conditions. The authors prove a review of some general mathematical models capable of producing this type of waves, and then describe thermoelastic solitons in detail from theoretical and applied points of view.
extraInfo: Editor-in-Chief Hetnarski, R., Springer, ISBN: 978-94-007-2738-0

title: Transient thermoelastic waves and dynamic problems, generation and propagation
extraInfo:
Roderick Melnik is the Encyclopedia Section Editor.


This editorial section on “Transient thermoelastic waves and dynamic problems, generation and propagation” includes the following entries:

  1. Lamb Waves in Homogeneous Isotropic Thermoelastic Plates by J. N. Sharma
  2. Surface Wave Propagation in a Thermoelastic Half-Space by Tsolo P. Ivanov, Radijanka Savova
  3. (a) Inhomogeneous Plane Waves in Thermoelasticity and (b) Acceleration Wave Propagation in Inhomogeneous Heat-Conducting Rods by Nigel H. Scott
  4. Thermoelastic Waves in Thin Bodies by Shih-Ming Hsu, Ching-Chung Yin 
  5. Propagation of Shock Waves in Thermoelastic Solids in View of Singular Surfaces by Tekin Gültop, Bahadir Alyavuz 
  6. (a) Ellipticity Condition and Acceleration Waves in Nonlinear Thermoelastic Solids and (b) Acceleration Waves in Nonlinear Thermoelastic Micropolar Media by Victor A. Eremeyev 
  7. Soliton-Like Thermoelastic Waves by Dmitry Strunin, Roderick Melnik 
  8. Acceleration Waves in Thermoelastic Materials with Voids by Brian Straughan 
  9. Thermoelastic Waves at an Interface Between Two Solids by Baljeet Singh 
  10. Wave Propagation in the Two-Temperature Theory of Thermoelasticity by Hamdy M. Youssef 
  11. (a) Harmonic Waves in an Anisotropic Medium Generated by Heat Sources Distributed Along the Plane, (b) Ray Expansion Theory, (c) Hyperbolic Thermoelasticity, Transient Dynamic Contact Problems, (d) D’Alembert Method in Dynamic Problems of Thermoelasticity, (e) Transient Thermoelastic Rayleigh Waves on the Surfaces of Bodies of Revolution, (f) Boundary-Value Problems Resulting in Thermoelastic Shock Wave Propagation, (g) Thermal Shock upon Thin-Walled Beams of Open Profile, (h) Harmonic Waves in an Anisotropic Medium Generated by Heat Sources Distributed Along the Plane, (i) Ray Method for Solving Boundary-Value Problems of Anisotropic Thermoelasticity with Thermal Relaxation by Yury A. Rossikhin, Marina V. Shitikova

  13. Skin Burn Injury Prediction by Weizhong Dai 
  14. Acceleration Waves in Layers of Isotropic Solids at Finite Temperatures by Carmela Currò, Giovanna Valenti 
  15. Thermoelastic Stresses, Variational Methods by Meir Shillor 
  16. Second Sound Waves in Solids by Swantje Bargmann 
  17. Harmonic Vibrations in Thermoelastic Cylinders by Vincenzo Tibullo 


Editor-in-Chief Hetnarski, R., Springer, 2014, LXXXIII, 6643 pages, in 11 volumes


ISBN: 978-94-007-2738-0, 2014.

title: Interdisciplinary Topics in Applied Mathematics, Modeling and Computational Science
abstract:
The Applied Mathematics, Modelling, and Computational Science (AMMCS) conference aims to promote interdisciplinary research and collaboration. The contributions in this volume cover the latest research in mathematical and computational sciences, modeling, and simulation as well as their applications in natural and social sciences, engineering and technology, industry, and finance.

The 2013 conference, the second in a series of AMMCS meetings, was held August 26—30 and organized in cooperation with AIMS and SIAM, with support from the Fields Institute in Toronto, and Wilfrid Laurier University. There were many young scientists at AMMCS-2013, both as presenters and as organizers. This proceedings contains refereed papers contributed by the participants of the AMMCS-2013 after the conference.

This volume is suitable for researchers and graduate students, mathematicians and engineers, industrialists, and anyone who would like to delve into the interdisciplinary research of applied and computational mathematics and its areas of applications.
journal: Springer Proceedings in Mathematics and Statistics

title: Mathematical and Computational Modeling: With Applications in Natural and Social Sciences, Engineering, and the Arts
abstract:
With an emphasis on the interdisciplinary nature of mathematical and computational modeling, Mathematical and Computational Modeling: With Applications in the Natural and Social Sciences, Engineering, and the Arts features chapters written by well-known, international experts in these fields and presents readers with a host of state-of-the-art achievements in the development of mathematical modeling and computational experiment methodology. The book is a valuable guide to the methods, ideas, and tools of applied and computational mathematics as they apply to other disciplines such as the natural and social sciences, engineering, and technology.  Mathematical and Computational Modeling: With Applications in the Natural and Social Sciences, Engineering, and the Arts also features:

Rigorous mathematical procedures and applications as the driving force behind mathematical innovation and discovery
Numerous examples from a wide range of disciplines to emphasize the multidisciplinary application and universality of applied mathematics and mathematical modeling
Original results on both fundamental theoretical and applied developments in diverse areas of human knowledge
Discussions that promote interdisciplinary interactions between mathematicians, scientists, and engineers
Mathematical and Computational Modeling: With Applications in the Natural and Social Sciences, Engineering, and the Arts is an ideal resource for professionals in various areas of mathematical and statistical sciences, modeling and simulation, physics, computer science, engineering, biology and chemistry, industrial, and computational engineering. The book also serves as an excellent textbook for graduate courses in mathematical modeling, applied mathematics, numerical methods, operations research, and optimization.

title: Mathematical and Computational Approaches in Advancing Modern Science and Engineering
abstract:
Focusing on five main groups of interdisciplinary problems, this book covers a wide range of topics in mathematical modeling, computational science and applied mathematics. It presents a wealth of new results in the development of modeling theories and methods, advancing diverse areas of applications and promoting interdisciplinary interactions between mathematicians, scientists, engineers and representatives from other disciplines.

The book offers a valuable source of methods, ideas, and tools developed for a variety of disciplines, including the natural and social sciences, medicine, engineering, and technology. Original results are presented on both the fundamental and applied level, accompanied by an ample number of real-world problems and examples emphasizing the interdisciplinary nature and universality of mathematical modeling, and providing an excellent outline of today’s challenges. Mathematical modeling, with applied and computational methods and tools, plays a fundamental role in modern science and engineering. It provides a primary and ubiquitous tool in the context making new discoveries, as well as in the development of new theories and techniques for solving key problems arising in scientific and engineering applications.

The contributions, which are the product of two highly successful meetings held jointly in Waterloo, Ontario, Canada on the main campus of Wilfrid Laurier University in June 2015, i.e. the International Conference on Applied Mathematics, Modeling and Computational Science, and the Annual Meeting of the Canadian Applied and Industrial Mathematics (CAIMS), make the book a valuable resource for any reader interested in a broader overview of the methods, ideas and tools involved in mathematical and computational approaches developed for other disciplines, including the natural and social sciences, engineering and technology.

title: Recent Progress and Modern Challenges in Applied Mathematics, Modeling and Computational Science
abstract:
This volume is an excellent resource for professionals in various areas of applications of mathematics, modeling, and computational science. It focuses on recent progress and modern challenges in these areas. The volume provides a balance between fundamental theoretical and applied developments, emphasizing the interdisciplinary nature of modern trends and detailing state-of-the-art achievements in Applied Mathematics, Modeling, and Computational Science. 

The chapters have been authored by international experts in their respective fields, making this book ideal for researchers in academia, practitioners, and graduate students. It can also serve as a reference in the diverse selected areas of applied mathematics, modelling, and computational sciences, and is ideal for interdisciplinary collaborations.

title: Coupled Mathematical Models for Physical and Biological Nanoscale Systems and Their Applications
abstract:
This volume gathers selected contributions from the participants of the Banff International Research Station (BIRS) workshop Coupled Mathematical Models for Physical and Biological Nanoscale Systems and their Applications, who explore various aspects of the analysis, modeling and applications of nanoscale systems, with a particular focus on low dimensional nanostructures and coupled mathematical models for their description.

Due to the vastness, novelty and complexity of the interfaces between mathematical modeling and nanoscience and nanotechnology, many important areas in these disciplines remain largely unexplored. In their efforts to move forward, multidisciplinary research communities have come to a clear understanding that, along with experimental techniques, mathematical modeling and analysis have become crucial to the study, development and application of systems at the nanoscale.

The conference, held at BIRS in autumn 2016, brought together experts from three different communities working in fields where coupled mathematical models for nanoscale and biosystems are especially relevant: mathematicians, physicists (both theorists and experimentalists), and computational scientists, including those dealing with biological nanostructures. Its objectives: summarize the state-of-the-art; identify and prioritize critical problems of major importance that require solutions; analyze existing methodologies; and explore promising approaches to addressing the challenges identified.

The contributions offer up-to-date introductions to a range of topics in nano and biosystems, identify important challenges, assess current methodologies and explore promising approaches. As such, this book will benefit researchers in applied mathematics, as well as physicists and biologists interested in coupled mathematical models and their analysis for physical and biological nanoscale systems that concern applications in biotechnology and medicine, quantum information processing and optoelectronics.
journal: Springer Proceedings in Mathematics & Statistics Book Series

title: Recent Advances in Mathematical and Statistical Methods for Scientific and Engineering Applications
abstract:
This book focuses on the recent development of methodologies and computation methods in mathematical and statistical modelling, computational science and applied mathematics. It emphasizes the development of theories and applications, and promotes interdisciplinary endeavour among mathematicians, statisticians, scientists, engineers and researchers from other disciplines.

The book provides ideas, methods and tools in mathematical and statistical modelling that have been developed for a wide range of research fields, including medical, health sciences, biology, environmental science, engineering, physics and chemistry, finance, economics and social sciences. It presents original results addressing real-world problems.

The contributions are products of a highly successful meeting held in August 2017 on the main campus of Wilfrid Laurier University, in Waterloo, Canada, the International Conference on Applied Mathematics, Modeling and Computational Science (AMMCS-2017). They make this book a valuable resource for readers interested not only in a broader overview of the methods, ideas and tools in mathematical and statistical approaches, but also in how they can attain valuable insights into problems arising in other disciplines.
journal: Springer Proceedings in Mathematics & Statistics Book Series

title: Recent Development in Mathematical, Statistical and Computational Sciences
abstract:
This book constitutes an up-to-date account of principles, methods, and tools for mathematical and statistical modelling in a wide range of research fields, including medicine, health sciences, biology, environmental science, engineering, physics, chemistry, computation, finance, economics, and social sciences. It presents original solutions to real-world problems, emphasizes the coordinated development of theories and applications, and promotes interdisciplinary collaboration among mathematicians, statisticians, and researchers in other disciplines.

Based on a highly successful meeting, the International Conference on Applied Mathematics, Modeling and Computational Science, AMMCS 2019, held from August 18 to 23, 2019, on the main campus of Wilfrid Laurier University, Waterloo, Canada, the contributions are the results of submissions from the conference participants. They provide readers with a broader view of the methods, ideas and tools used in mathematical, statistical and computational sciences.
journal: Springer Proceedings in Mathematics & Statistics Book Series
extraInfo: Hardcover ISBN 978-3-030-63590-9 eBook ISBN 978-3-030-63591-6 Waterloo, Canada, August 18–23, 2019

title: Special Issue "Recent Advances in the Application of Mathematical and Computational Models in Biomedical Science and Engineering"
extraInfo: Mathematical modeling in biomedical engineering plays a vital role in understanding complex multidisciplinary interactions and processes at the organ, tissue and cellular scales. Mathematical modeling serves as a low-cost but powerful alternative for optimizing, predicting, and improving existing healthcare protocols, systems and equipment. This Special Issue aims at collecting original research articles related to the advancement and development of novel mathematical models broadly applied across a wide range of biomedical engineering and medical physics, including diagnostic, therapeutic, imaging, and interventional applications.

title: Innovation in minimally invasive therapies, biosensing, and screening: Data-driven models, complex networks, and experiments
extraInfo: This Research Topic presents a collection of novel modelling, computational, experimental, and clinical studies in the field of minimally invasive diagnostics, and disease treatments targeting cancer, cardiovascular diseases, neurodegenerative disorders and respiratory diseases.

title: Special Issue "Recent Advances in the Application of Mathematical and Computational Models in Biomedical Science and Engineering 2.0"
extraInfo: Mathematical modeling in biomedical engineering plays a vital role in understanding complex multidisciplinary interactions and processes at the organ, tissue and cellular scales. Mathematical modeling serves as a low-cost but powerful alternative for optimizing, predicting, and improving existing healthcare protocols, systems and equipment. This Special Issue aims at collecting original research articles related to the advancement and development of novel mathematical models broadly applied across a wide range of biomedical engineering and medical physics, including diagnostic, therapeutic, imaging, and interventional applications.

title: Addressing Modern Challenges in the Mathematical, Statistical, and Computational Sciences
journal: Springer Proceedings in Mathematics & Statistics Book Series
